title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part III (Sec 5 to 11)
text:
Session Goals
By the end of today, you can:

Find a Normal Approximation of an Empty-Model
Evaluate the Normal Approximation
Use the Normal Approximation to Estimate Event Propbabilities
Compute Z-Score
Use Z-Score and Probability to Compare Hypotheses

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part III (Sec 5 to 11)
text:
Empirical Rule is an Approximation




- Area within 1 SD from the mean:  0.6826895 
- Area within 2 SD from the mean:  0.9544997 
- Area within 3 SD from the mean:  0.9973002

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part III (Sec 5 to 11)
section: Fitting a Normal to a Distribution
text:
Fitting a Normal to a Distribution

Student Thumb Length:

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part III (Sec 5 to 11)
text:
Evaluate the Fit

Normal Approximation of Student Thumb Length:




Recall Empirical Rule

\(P(\mu-\sigma, \mu+\sigma)=68\%\)
\(P(\mu-2\sigma, \mu+2\sigma)=95\%\)
\(P(\mu-3\sigma, \mu+3\sigma)=99.7\%\)

















Proportions:




1-SD: 0.6942675      2-SD: 0.9363057     3-SD: 0.9872611




Not a Great Approximation; but OK!

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part III (Sec 5 to 11)
text:
Generic vs Standard Normal




Recall Empirical Rule

\(P(\mu-\sigma, \mu+\sigma)=68\%\)
\(P(\mu-2\sigma, \mu+2\sigma)=95\%\)
\(P(\mu-3\sigma, \mu+3\sigma)=99.7\%\)


















Each Normal is equivalent to Standard Normal


\[X\sim N(\mu, \sigma) \Leftrightarrow Z\sim N(0, 1)\]
\[X = \mu + Z\cdot \sigma \Leftrightarrow Z=\frac{X-\mu}{\sigma}\]

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part III (Sec 5 to 11)
text:
Interpretation of \(Z\)

\(Z=\frac{X-\mu}{\sigma}\):   \(X\) is \(Z\)-many standard deviation above \(\mu\)
Example: \(T\sim N(75, 5)\):

\(T=82\)
Equivalant \(Z=1.4 (=\frac{82-75}{5})\)
\(T=82\) is \(1.4\) standard deviation above the mean

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part III (Sec 5 to 11)
text:
Application of \(Z\):  Within Group Comparison




  Gender     mean       sd
1 female 64.51830 2.662054
2   male 69.50222 2.937647





Which one is taller in their group:

A 66-inch female student
A 72-inch female student





















Female: Z = (68.00-64.52)/(2.662) 
    = 1.308

Male: Z = (72.00-69.50)/(2.938) 
    = 0.850

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part III (Sec 5 to 11)
text:
Application of \(Z\):  Between Group Decision


A student is 68 inches; is the student male or female?

















Which is more unlikely?

From female group? \(P(Height > 68)\)
From male group? \(P(Height < 68)\)





Female: P(Height>68)=P(Z>1.31)=0.0893
Male: P(Height<68)=P(Z<-0.51)=0.2667

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Session Goals
By the end of today you can:

Explain what a residual is
Show why the mean minimizes sum of squares
Explain why SS grows with sample size
Define variance as average squared error
Interpret SD as typical prediction error

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
DATA = MODEL + ERROR
Recall: \[\text{DATA} = \text{MODEL} + \text{ERROR}\]

For the empty (simple) model: \[\begin{array}\text{Model = Center} &= \hat{y_i}\\
\text{Data} &= y_i\\
\text{Residual} = e_i &= y_i - \hat{y_i}
\end{array}\]


Total Error (SS) as Model Performance

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Group Activity


Let population be \[5, 7, 7, 12, 20\]
Find mode, median, and mean.
Evaluate Different Simple Models

Choose one center \[\text{Centers} = 0, 5, 7, 10, \bar y, 12, 15, 17, \text{ or } 20\]

Calculate Residuals and SS

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text: Checking Results

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text: Plotting the Results

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Lesson Learned

SS~Center relation is U-shaped
Minimum SS happens at \(\hat y_i = \bar y\).




The mean minimizes: \[SS = \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \hat{y_i})^2\]

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Why SS?


Uses Mean (Balances Error)
Measures Variability



Check Application of Variability






Original Data











Stretched Data

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Population Size and SS


What happens if we double the data size? \[5, 7, 7, 12, 20, 5, 7, 7, 12, 20\]

Does the average change?
Do the residuals change?
How does SS change?

Let’s check:

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
SS and Relative Variability












SS represents variability.
Variability changes relative to the sample size.
Relative Variability (Variance) = SS/Size

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Population Variance vs. SS


Population Variance = \[\sigma^2 = \frac{SS}{n}\]

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Sample Variance
Random Samples and Sample Variance

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Sampling Distribution of Variance
Using the Law of Large Numbers for Distribution




















Mean Sample Variance \(\approx (4/5)\) Population Variance

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Sample Variance

Sample Variance = \(s^2 = \frac{SS}{n-1}\)
Sample Standard Deviation = \(s=\sqrt{\frac{SS}{n-1}}\)

A good measure of model error.

The typical size of prediction error when using the mean.


R Functions











٫# Important Distinction



Quantity
Measures





Residual
Individual error



SS
Total squared error



Variance
Average squared error



SD
Typical prediction error

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Exit Question
If we change one value to be extremely large, what happens?

Mean changes a little
Mean changes a lot
Variance increases
Both B and C

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Sec 1 to 4
text:
Big Idea Today
The mean is not arbitrary.


It is the value that minimizes squared prediction error.


Variance and SD measure how wrong that model is.

title: CourseKata Chapter 4
text:
Models of Variability

Chance Model: Variability is only by Chance \[GradePredict = \text{Other Stuff} (Unexplained)\]
One Explanatory: Gender explains some variability \[GradePredict = Gender + \text{Other Stuff}\]
Two Explanatory: Both Gender and Interest explain some variability \[GradePredict = Gender + Interest + \text{Other Stuff}\]

title: CourseKata Chapter 4
text:
How to Compate Models (Hypothesis)


Explained variability: outcome (residuals) depends on explanatory value

Residuals = Observed - Predicted (or expected)

More explained variablity \(\rightarrow\) Better model

title: CourseKata Chapter 4
text:
Research Design
Association or Causation?

Observational Studies: Random Sampling

Unbiased Association
Other variables may also explain variation

Designed Experiments: Random Assignment

Eliminating the impact of other variables
Revealing Causation

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Explain what a distribution is (pattern of variation in a variable)
Build and interpret histograms
Describe a distribution using shape, center, spread, and unusual features
Compute the five-number summary and interpret quartiles
Create and interpret box plots
Identify outliers using the 1.5×IQR rule

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Big idea
A distribution is the pattern of variation in a variable.


We look at all values together
We summarize and visualize the pattern





























What are distribution characteristics in each case?

What a histogram shows

















x-axis: values (bins)
y-axis: counts (or density)
reveals shape + spread quickly

text:
Bin width matters





















Which bin width best shows the overall pattern without “too much noise”?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
section: A checklist for describing a distribution
text:
A checklist for describing a distribution

Shape: symmetric? skewed? unimodal/bimodal?



Center: typical value

mode, median or mean





Spread: how variable? how concentrated?

Range \((=Max - Min)\), Standard Deviation, IQR





Weird things: gaps, clusters, outliers

Outliers: far away from typical \(\equiv\) unlikely tail

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
section: Five numbers that tell a lot
text:
Five numbers that tell a lot

min, Q1, median, Q3, max



Population [of Countries]:


      min    Q1 median     Q3    max     mean       sd   n missing
     0.29 4.455  10.48 31.225 1304.5 44.14545 145.4893 143       0

What is the population of the largest country?
Could data be skewed?
What does Q1 mean in plain language?
What does IQR(\(=Q_3-Q_1\)) represent?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Quartiles = cutpoints

Q1: about 25% of values are below
Median: about 50% below
Q3: about 75% below












“Half the countries have a population _______.”
“The population of a quarter of countries is _______.”

text:

Index Distribution









Index Distribution by Gender

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
The 1.5×IQR rule

Lower fence: Q1 − 1.5×IQR
Upper fence: Q3 + 1.5×IQR
Values beyond fences are flagged as outliers




 min Q1 median Q3 max
  45 67     70 76 110

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text: Distribution of Categorical Data

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Characteristics of Categorical Distributions:

Shape: Not applicable (Location? position?)
Center: The tallest bar
Spread: How different equal bars are

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Variability in Categorical Distributions (Advanced):

Variability is measured different ways:

The larger the value; the more equal the bars.
Gini: \(1-\sum_{i=1}^k p_i^2 \quad \in [0, (k-1)/k]\)
Shannon Entropy: \(H=−\sum_{i=1}^k p_i \log(p_i) \quad \in [0, \log(k)]\)

Variation is the point

We reveal patterns by sorting and counting.
We use patterns to find  unusual things  exceptions  outliers

x <- c(2, 1, 3, 3, 2, 3, 1, 2, 1)

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Explain population vs. sample
Explain why random + independent sampling matters
Describe tidy data (rows/columns) and work with data frames
Recognize and handle missing data (NA) in a principled way
Create and recode variables to answer a question

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Big ideas

Population: the universe of cases we want to learn about

Sample: the cases we actually measure
Two key choices in any sampling plan:

Who counts as part of the population?
How do we select cases from that population?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Random & independent sampling

Random: each case has an equal chance of being selected

Independent: picking one case doesn’t change the chance of picking another

Why we care:

Many statistical methods assume your sample is (approximately) random and independent.
When these assumptions fail, conclusions can be misleading.

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: Try it: sampling variation with a “fake population”
text:
Try it: sampling variation with a “fake population”








Now take a random sample of 10 and compare.

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text: Visual: histogram of your sample (n = 10)

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Think, Pair, Share:

What do you expect if we repeat the sampling again?










What happens if we increase the sample size?









Discuss: Which sample looks “more representative” of the population? Why?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
The tidy-data idea
A useful default structure:

Each column is a variable

Each row is a case (observation)

Each type of case belongs in its own table

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Meet coursekata data frame: Fingers








Think:
- What are the cases?
- What are the variables?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Selecting a few columns (CourseKata-style)








Often we only want a few rows, too:

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Filtering rows (subsetting cases)
Example: keep only Gender == "female".








Question: - How many females are in this sample?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: What is missing data in R?
text:
What is missing data in R?

R uses the special value NA (“not available”) to represent missingness.


















NA is not the same as the text "NA".

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text: Identify missing values

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Two common strategies

Drop rows with missing values (sometimes OK, sometimes not)










Filter only the rows you need (more targeted)

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Activity: “missingness decisions” (group work)
In groups of 3–4:

Imagine SSLast is important to your analysis.
Decide which approach you’d use:

na.omit() on the whole data frame
targeted filter() for just SSLast
something else


Be ready to justify your choice in 1–2 sentences.

Creating a summary variable (logical)

Recoding: turn a quantitative variable into categories
Example: make a “HighRatio” indicator (above 1 vs not).








Now cross-tab by Gender:

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Wrap-up: what we just practiced

Sampling → variability shows up even when the population is “known”
Tidy data → rows = cases, columns = variables
Missing data → NA requires explicit handling
New variables → make your analysis easier (and your models possible)

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Explain what Data Generating Process (DGP) means.
Use bottom‑up vs top‑down thinking to connect data ↔︎ DGP
Simulate a DGP with sample() / resample() and visualize results
Explain sampling variation and why small samples can look “weird”
Use simulations to see the law of large numbers in action

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
Data Generating Proccess (DGP)

Distributions Represents Variability in Data








































Known Population

Fixed Variability








A Small Sample

Much different








A Large Sample;

Different, but less






Variation in part depends on the DGP

Key Idea: “What DGP generated population variability?”

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
Quick example: bus wait times (source)





distribution of some 60,000 waiting times at a NY bus stop




DGP thinking = using context to explain the distribution:

schedules?
passenger behavior?
delays, traffic, bunching?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
Two moves statisticians make

Top‑down: Theory of DGP → Expected Distribution




































Bottom‑up: Observed Distribution → Predict Population/DGP

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
Sampling and Resampling

Sampling 1 Roll of a Die












Pair prompt:

Why do we get different numbers?
What stays the same?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
GDP: Independent Samples

Sample with replacement (Independet Samples)












What happens if replace = FALSE (default)?
How the distribution resembles the population?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
GDP: Large Independent Samples

1000 independent samples:












Which one (10 or 1000) looks more like the population?
Which one has more sampling variation?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
Weird populations can exist









This is a strange population shape -— but it’s still a valid distribution.
Could a sample represent this weird distribution?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
Sampling from the Weird Population





















Which sample “reveals” the W-shape better?
Which DGP is more variable?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.10–3.13
text:
Law of Large Numbers

As sample size increases:

the sample distribution tends to resemble the population distribution more closely.

A single small sample could do the same but less likely to do so:

Small samples can be misleading.

Law of Large Numbers works better on Statistics than Distribution! Why?

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
Session Goals
By the end of today, you can:

Explain error in mathematical & statistical models
Choose a statistic to represent a distribution
Compute and interpret residuals
Use lm() to build a simple model based on mean.
Use predict() and resid() to evaluate the performance of a model.

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
Mathematical Modeling
Assume we need to estimate the area of a circle:








Using squares










Using octagons










Area = Estimate + Error



We can control the error

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
Statistical Modeling of Distributions


Students’ Height:










Two Important questions:

How to estimate the distribution?
How to predict future samples?

Answer:

Model the DGP process
Estimate the model parameters.
Control the error as much as possible.

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
A Simple DGP Model


Student’s Height:









 min   Q1 median   Q3  max
  59 63.5   65.5 68.1 76.5


     mean       sd   n missing
 65.94682 3.547939 157       0




DGP: Data (Height) = Model + Error
Estimating Model (Center):

Mode (Most likely): \((62.5, 67.5]\)
Median (Middle number): \(65.5\)
Mean (Center of mass): \(65.95\)

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
Evaluating A DGP Model

DGP: Data (Height) = Model + Error





Estimating Model (Center):

Mode (Most likely): \((62.5, 67.5]\)
Median (Middle number): \(65.5\)
Mean (Center of mass): \(65.95\)





Estimating Error (Residual)

Mode:

Residual\(=1_{[Height==Mode]} \in \{0,1\}\)

Median & Mean:

Residual\(=Height - Center\)

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
A Toy Problem (continue):
Predicting the next random selection from: \(2, 2, 2, 4, 6, 12\)
Repeate 15-20 times:





Guess the next value
Record it under Guess



Roll a die (real or digital)
Use it to pick the next observation.
Record the observation under Actual.



Compute Match and Diff columns.
How good was your guessing procedure?

title: CourseKata Chapter 5

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text: Simulation Results

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
Mean + Residual as Simple Model


Mean:

Balances Residuals: \(\sum e_i=\sum (y_i-\bar{y}) = 0\)
Minimizes \(\sum e_i^2=\sum (y_i-\bar{y})^2\)

R functions:

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
Models and Explaning Variability


Mean-Model is the Null Hypothesis

All variations is due to chance

The Alternative Hypothesis:

Added variables can explain some variability

title: CourseKata Chapter 5
text:
Statistical Modeling Notation



Modeling Observed Data by Mean

Data = Observed Mean + Residual \[y_i = b_0 + e_i\]

\(b_0 = \bar y\) and
\(e_i = y_i - \bar y\)





Modeling (Population) GDP by Mean

Data = Population Mean + Error \[y_i = \beta_0 + \varepsilon_i\]

\(\beta_0 = \mu\) and
\(\varepsilon_i = y_i - \mu\)

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Session Goals
By the end of today, you can:

Simulate a sampling distribution of the mean
Connect LLN to sampling distributions
Identify unusual (unexpected) events
See why normal distributions appear naturally

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Statistics Are Random Variables



A statistic summarizes a sample.
Categorical → proportion
Quantitative: mean, SD, median, …



Random samples → Variable statistics


Distribution of Statistics:

What is its mean?
What is its variance?
What is its distribution shape?

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Law of Large Numbers (LLN)

Estimating the Distribution of a Statistic:

Use a large number of observed statistic
The mean converges faster than the distribution

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Sampling Distribution of the Mean


Steps:

Draw random sample
Compute mean
Repeat many times
Plot distribution of sample means

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Sampling Distribution for Size \(n\)























What do you notice?
What happens if a larger \(n\) is used?

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Key Patterns
As sample size increases:

Mean of sample means ≈ population mean (LLN)
Variance decreases \[Var(\bar{Y}) = \frac{\sigma^2}{n}\]
Distribution becomes smoother

More possible sample means.

Shape becomes more symmetric (bell-shaped)

Central Limit Theorem

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Central Limit Theorem (CLT)


As \(n\) increases,

\(\bar Y\) distribution approaches a Normal shape
with a mean equal to the population mean \(\mu\)
and a smaller variance \(\frac{\sigma^2}{n}\)

In other words: for large \(n\)’s \[\bar Y \hat \sim N(\mu, \sigma/\sqrt{n})\]

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
What is a Large \(n\)?

Any \(n\) works for \(Y\sim N(\mu, \sigma)\)
\(n\ge30\) is good for approximately symmetric \(Y\)-distributions.
For heavily skewed distribution of \(Y\), use simulation to check.

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text: Checling \(n\) by Simulation

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Normal Density & Empirical Rule

Normal Distribution & Empirical Rule:

68% of values fall in \((\mu-\sigma, \mu+\sigma)\)
95% of values fall in \((\mu-2\sigma, \mu+2\sigma)\)
99.7% of values fall in \((\mu-3\sigma, \mu+3\sigma)\)

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Unusual Events
Expected events (e.g. sample mean = population mean) could be unusual:

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Unexpected Unusual Events (Tails)
Events away from expected events









Farther away from the center: Lower tail probability

title: CourseKata Chapter 6: Part II
text:
Testing Claims (Hypothesis Testing)

Claim: The die used is fair (\(H_0\))
Roll a dies 40 times and get \(\bar Y = 4.3\)
Is it too far? Is it too unlikely?
